en.value: Your account is all set up.
Thanks. Yep, this plan covers accidental damage. Great - so that'll be $45 and it'll be ready for pickup in a week. Did you want to pay now or next week?
You can [k]look up[/k] phone providers online.
Yes, I [k]printed[/k] a copy. Here you go.
I pay rent on the first day of the month.
I have to [k]find[/k] a new routine.
Match the sentences to the correct categories.
Hi there, how's it going? Let me know if you need help with anything.
Thanks... Here you go. By the way, [k]do[/k] you do a student discount?
Select the question that is grammatically correct.
the person who pays to live in the apartment

Ken, a student in Sydney, wants a new mobile phone contract. On the next screen, you will listen to his conversation with Sam, a shop assistant. First, let's preview some of the words and phrases you will hear:
It's fine to ask "Do you want a receipt?", but "Did you want a receipt?" is more polite.
Because he's a student, Ken can get [k]$5[/k] off his [k]bill[/k] for the first six months.
[k]I pay rent[/k] on the first day of the month.
What [k]did[/k] you eat? How [k]was[/k] the weather?
Match the words with their definitions.
Hey, actually I'm looking to get a new mobile phone contract.
25 gig? That might not be enough data for me...
What [k]did[/k] you have for dinner last night?
Past simple: Did you have any other questions? (polite)
Ken's height, weight and favourite food
I've just moved to Istanbul, so I have a new routine.
This plan lets you make as many local and national calls as you want.
Ken's full name and contact information
This person will buy an apartment in Seville.
Match the questions to the correct categories.
What does Ken use his phone for?
Yeah, that's absolutely fine. Did you have any other questions?
Do you want tea or coffee?
We say "rent an apartment" when you live in an apartment you do not own. Rent is also the name of the fee a tenant pays their landlord.
Dealing with life in a new country - Past simple questions
Present simple: Do you have any other questions? (casual)

Right, let me show you some of our plans. Actually, we're doing this great offer at the moment. For $85 per month you get this brand new smartphone with 50GB of [k]data[/k], unlimited calls and texts, plus 1,000 international minutes.
Ken's daily texting and streaming habits
What is included in the $10-per-month deal?
Hi, can I please [k]open[/k] a bank account?
What time do you get up?
Sam, the shop assistant, asks Ken lots of questions in the "past simple". We often use the past tense to be polite.
What kind of phone contract does Ken want?
Select the polite auxiliary verb to complete the question.
Select the words in the correct order.
The word "did" (past tense of the verb "do") is the main action in this question.
The main action is "arrive". The auxiliary verb "did" shows that this question is about a completed action in the past.
We use the verb "to sign" with various documents, such as contracts.
If you want to call someone what do you need?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Thank you, madam. Did you want a receipt?

So far, we've practised using the "past simple" to talk about completed actions in the past. We also use the "past simple" as a more polite alternative to the "present simple". Let's see some examples:
The person who rents an apartment is the tenant, and the person who lets the apartment is the landlord.
We're doing this great offer at the moment.
on the first day of the month.
The plan Ken chooses has a monthly price of [k]$50[/k].
You must [k]sign a tenancy agreement[/k] before you receive the keys.

Sure, we have a range of different SIM-only contracts. I'll just get the info. Bear with me a sec... Okay, so this [k]plan[/k] is quite popular. It costs $10 a month and for that you get 1GB of data plus 600 minutes of calls and 1,000 texts. But as you can see, we have different plans to suit different needs. What do you mainly use your phone for? Calls, texts, data?
You're welcome! Was there anything else you needed help with today?
Yes / no question: Did he go to the gym?
the person who owns the apartment
Now you will listen to Sam take Ken's customer details. Before listening, check that you understand the following words and phrases:
This person does not yet have a Colombian phone contract.
You must sign a tenancy agreement before you receive the keys.
We've studied the structure of questions in the "past simple". Here are the main patterns to remember:
Have you seen my mobile anywhere?
I have to find a new routine.
You can [k]look up[/k] phone providers online.
Good [k]stuff[/k]. Thank you for coming in today. Have a great day!
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Wh- question: Why did he go to the gym?
Match the questions to the verb tenses.
We [h]had[/h] a great time. The beaches [h]were[/h] beautiful.
1KB of data, 600 minutes of calls and 10,000 texts.
We can also use the verb "to complete" when we talk about filling out forms.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
She dropped it the other day and the screen [k]broke[/k].
Match the word with the correct definition.
Right, so how does this plan [k]sound[/k] to you? You get 25GB of data and unlimited texts and minutes, all for only $40 a month.

We use the following structure to form a question in the "past simple":

(Wh- question word +) "did" + subject + verb (+ extra information)

Remember, the most common wh- question words are: when, which, what, who, where, why and how.
I have to [k]find a new routine[/k].
Erm... Oh yeah. There was one other thing actually. Do you do repairs? I've got my girlfriend's phone here. She dropped it the other day and the screen [k]broke[/k].
Match each phrasal verb with its meaning.
internet content delivered to mobile phones
Select the documents that often go with the verb "to sign".
I want to open a bank account.
I'm looking to get a SIM-only deal (Part 1)
Yeah, that sounds good. I'll [k]go[/k] for that one.

Ken says "mobile phone". People whose English is influenced by British English tend to say "mobile phone" or just "mobile", while in areas where US English is more influential people generally say "cell phone" or "cell". But as landlines become less common, speakers of English everywhere often simply refer to their mobile as a "phone".
1MB of data, 600 minutes of calls and 100 texts.
I pay rent on the first day of the month, but my sister pays rent weekly.
What time did you get up?
How does this plan sound to you?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Yeah, I've got it somewhere. Here it is.
[k]I am[/k] [k]going[/k] [k]to the embassy[/k] [k]to ask about[/k] [k]my passport.[/k]
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
I need to find the embassy.
Type the missing word to form a polite question.
Okay... Well, I have my own phone which is still pretty good. To be honest, I'm looking to get a SIM-only deal. Do you do contracts with just a [k]SIM[/k] card?
It's a monthly contract, and you can cancel any time.
I will get a phone contract when I arrive in Colombia.
Let's continue our review of the "past simple" with a recap of question forms. Look at these sentences to review what you learned in A2:
Thank you, madam. [k]Did[/k] you want a receipt?
Did she have a care plan with us? - Yes, I [k]printed[/k] a copy.
I'm looking to get a SIM-only deal (Part 2)
When opening a new bank account you may be asked to provide identification.
Let me see... Yeah, this is fairly common, unfortunately. We can fix it. Did she have a care plan with us?
I will rent an apartment in Seville during my year abroad.
A passport is an example of identification.
Did you want tea or coffee?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Ken would like a new mobile phone number.
Sure, no [k]worries[/k]. Please enter your name, email address and home address here for me.
What is this person looking for?
I will look up the meaning of the word.
is money the tenant pays to the landlord.
Thanks. Right, that's all the information I needed. Your account is all [k]set[/k] up. I'll just install your new SIM card for you now - bear with me a sec. Right, you're [k]good[/k] to go.
What do we call the person who owns the apartment you rent?
You can go to the embassy for advice about your visa.
Have you recently moved to a new country? When you arrive in a new place you often have a lot of things to organise. Let's explore some of them now!
When you move to a new place, you might have to find a new gym, supermarket or language classes. Day-to-day activities like this form part of a "routine."
This will only take a couple of minutes. I just need to check, did you want to keep your existing phone number or would you like a new one?
No worries. How about this plan? It comes with 50GB of data, [k]unlimited[/k] texts and calls, plus 1,200 international minutes - and that costs just $50 a month.

Listen to the audio. What is Priya looking for?
Listen to Sam take Ken's customer details. What benefit does Ken get for being a student?
She bought a new phone last week.
1GB of data, 600 minutes of calls and 1,000 texts.
Great! Now if you come with me to the counter, I just need to take [k]down[/k] your details.
Present simple: Do you want to pay now or next week? (casual)
I need a new one, please.
Did you [k]want[/k] any side dishes with that?
Who are the people involved when you rent an apartment?
Fill in the gap using the correct form of the verb "to want".
Fill in the gap using the image.
I don't make calls so much. I just send texts, and I use a lot of data. I [k]stream[/k] lots of videos, music...that kind of thing.
Listen to the conversation between the customer, Ken, and the shop assistant, Sam. What does Ken mainly use his phone for?
I paid rent at the end of the month.
I need to find an apartment!
What details do you think the shop assistant needs?
Please provide at least two different types of identification, such as a passport or identity card.
Match the start and end of the following phrases.

When the main verb is "to be", we use the following structure to form a question in the "past simple":

(Wh- question word +) "was" or "were" + subject (+ extra information)
I will [k]look[/k] [k]up[/k] the meaning of the word.
Grammar: Questions in the past simple
Hi, can I please [k]open a bank account?[/k]
You must sign your bank card before you use it.
Yes, we do. [k]Did[/k] you have any student ID? You can get $5 off your bill for the first six months.
You must provide two types of identification.
This person already has a bank account.
Past simple: Did you want to pay now or next week? (polite)
[k]Did[/k] you want to keep your existing phone number?
Match the verb with the rest of the phrase.
